repnme.cdata!:
China - Chongqing Industrial Pollution
            Control and Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Chongqing Industrial Pollution
            Control and Reform Project for China had a satisfactory
            outcome, with likely sustainability, moderate institutional
            development impact, and satisfactory performances by both
            the Bank and Borrower.  Despite cancellation of most of the
            loan amount, the project's key development objectives
            were substantially achieved.   Some components were
            cancelled including: steel plant restructuring and
            relocation; line-of-credit component; and surplus labor
            re-employment support.  Lessons Learned were in the areas of
            Bank procedures and covenants as well as procurement.
            Lengthy Bank preparation and appraisal procedures, entailing
            project preparation studies and determining the feasibility
            of sub-borrowers, are not appropriate for projects in
            dynamic sectors such as industry, especially for economies
            in transition.  Also, sub-borrowers under intense
            competitive pressure are less likely to be able to meet
            financial covenants.  While assurance is needed that the
            sub-borrowers are creditworthy and have a satisfactory
            business plan, financing terms ought to be responsive to
            changing competitive conditions and product market dynamics.
            Requiring sub-borrowers to assume the foreign exchange risk
            burdens them, especially if the sub-borrower is unable to
            hedge against such a risk, particularly in China.
            Procurement was delayed due to: (a) lack of sufficient
            understanding by the Borrower and its agencies of Bank
            procurement procedures; and (b) the Chongqing Environmental
            Protection Bureau's (CEPB's) nebulous internal
            procedures for reviewing and approving bid documents.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Chongqing Industrial Pollution
            Control and Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Chongqing Industrial Pollution
            Control and Reform Project supports the Bank's lending
            strategy in China within a policy framework that focuses on
            enhanced industrial pollution control linked to enterprise
            reform and technological restructuring. Moreover, the
            project supports the government of China's efforts to
            help relatively underdeveloped regions in the interior catch
            up with the country's faster growing coastal areas. To
            achieve these objectives, the project will help Chongqing
            municipality (CM) to: 1) achieve a significant reduction in
            pollution and restructure productive facilities from its
            most polluting industry, iron and steel; 2) establish a
            strategy and prepare a long-term plan to achieve a major
            reduction in pollution for the whole industrial sector by,
            inter alia, increasing the effectiveness of CM's
            environmental regulatory framework and pollution management
            capability; and 3) initiate a pilot effort to assist
            industrial enterprises in other industrial sectors to
            restructure their productive facilities, control pollution
            and transform themselves into modern corporations. The
            project will include the following components: 1) support
            for development and implementation of economic and
            environmental policy agendas and action plans; 2) relocation
            of the city's two major polluting steel mills; 3)
            restructuring of advisory facilities for industrial
            enterprises; 4) a line of credit to support a pilot program
            in industrial enterprise reform, pollution control and
            restructuring; and 5) technical assistance to strengthen
            environmental regulation, surplus labor reemployment and
            innovation in state asset management.

696504.trustfund:
TF022529-PHRD-SHENYANG ENGINEERING PROJECT,TF022776-PHRD-CHONGGING INDUST.REF.& POLLU./REC.,TF022771-PHRD-CHONGGING INDUS.REFORM
            & POLL./BANK,TF025460-PHRD-INDUSTRIAL RESTRUCTURING PROJ.,TF028471-GEF1 PDF C:CHINA EFFICIENT IND.
            BOILERS PROJECT,TF029174-PHRD-CHONGQING INDUSTRIAL
            REFORM PROJ.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Chongqing Industrial Reform and
            Pollution Control Project : environmental assessment report
            : summary

abstracts.cdata!:
The Chongqing Special Steel Company
            (CSSC) is located in a very densely populated area in the
            city of Chongqing in Sichuan Province.  The steel making
            facilities are a major source of air and water pollution and
            are scheduled to be shutdown in 1996-1998.  As part of the
            Chongqing Industrial Reform and Pollution Control Project, a
            modern steelmaking plant capable of complying with accepted
            environmental standards will be constructed.  The project is
            composed of production and supplementary equipment which
            include scrap processing, electric furnace steelmaking,
            refining furnace, continuous casting, steel slag processing
            and oxygen station, boiler station, compressed air station
            and water processing.  The pollution sources produced by the
            new facilities are waste gas, waste water, solid waste, air
            power and machine noises.  This report is an environmental
            assessment of the project.  Its environmental impacts
            include impacts on the ecological and social environment,
            and living quality.  The impacts may be caused by site
            selection, potential accidents, activities during the
            construction period, and normal operation of the new
            facilities.  The results of the environmental impact
            assessment show that: 1) the new facilities will have a
            slight effect on air quality at any location; and 2) when
            the existing plant is shutdown, air quality in the area near
            the plant will be significantly improved by decreased
            concentrations of Nox, SO2 and TPS.
